Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: OPTIMUS - An Innovative Modular Turbomachinery System for Small Satellite Launch Propulsion Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I Project is to improve new pumps for the satellite launch industry. Small satellites support many applications such as global Internet and communication coverage, as well as earth and environmental imaging. The proposed technology will support propulsion systems with higher efficiency. This project will explore high-performing design and manufacturing techniques required to create a 3D printed, high-efficiency propulsion sub-system. The system is designed to be modular, scalable, and adaptable by leveraging many advanced design and manufacturing techniques such as additive manufacturing.

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will support the research and development of the launch industry’s first commercially available turbine-driven pump system for the satellite launch industry. The innovation reduces typical turbopump cost and part count by a factor of 10, and can be rapidly configured to meet requirements for thrust, engine cycle, and propellant combinations. The proposed project will explore the cost-performance trade space for a novel rocket engine turbopump system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I Project was to improve access to space by making critical enabling propulsion technologies for the satellite launch industry more readily available. The small satellite industry supports many applications such as global Internet and communication coverage, daily earth imaging, and environmental monitoring. By increasing the availability of higher efficiency and lower cost propulsion systems, the proposed innovation will support an emerging space-based economy and lead to increased payload capacity for the supporting launch vehicles and improved economics associated with getting the space industry’s most transformative satellite technologies into orbit.

This project explored unique design and manufacturing techniques to create a 3D printed, mass-producible propulsion system. The concept was envisioned and proven to be a modular, scalable, and adaptable product offering and leverages many advanced manufacturing techniques such as additive manufacturing. Results of the 10-month R&D effort successfully demonstrated that extreme part consolidation for complex rocket systems was possible – resulting in a part-count reduction of 100 to 10 when compared to a typical solution. In addition, the research explored and demonstrated the design, analysis, and manufacturing requirements to mass-produce such as system in support of future demands for highly capable launch vehicles. Ultimately, commercialization of the innovation is expected to result in a 10x reduction in recurring costs compared to the current state-of-the-art equivalent and provide the groundwork for the first commercially available off-the-shelf, high-performing, turbine-driven pump (turbopump) system for the satellite launch industry.

 


Last Modified: 06/01/2021
Modified by: Ryan Rollon

By increasing the availability of higher efficiency and lower cost propulsion systems, the proposed innovation will support an emerging space-based economy and lead to increased payload capacity for the supporting launch vehicles and improved economics associated with getting the space industry’s most transformative satellite technologies into orbit. This project explored unique design and manufacturing techniques to create a 3D printed, mass-producible propulsion system. The concept was envisioned and proven to be a modular, scalable, and adaptable product offering and leverages many advanced manufacturing techniques such as additive manufacturing. Results of the 10-month R&D effort successfully demonstrated that extreme part consolidation for complex rocket systems was possible – resulting in a part-count reduction of 100 to 10 when compared to a typical solution. In addition, the research explored and demonstrated the design, analysis, and manufacturing requirements to mass-produce such as system in support of future demands for highly capable launch vehicles. Ultimately, commercialization of the innovation is expected to result in a 10x reduction in recurring costs compared to the current state-of-the-art equivalent and provide the groundwork for the first commercially available off-the-shelf, high-performing, turbine-driven pump (turbopump) system for the satellite launch industry.
